title: The Flourishing Business of Fake YouTube Views
abstract: Plays can be bought for pennies and delivered in bulk, inflating videos’ popularity and making the social media giant vulnerable to manipulation.

title: $100 Million Was Once Big Money for a Start-Up. Now, It’s Common.
abstract: Known as a mega-round in Silicon Valley, large-scale fund raising is producing a frenzy around tech companies with enough reach and momentum to absorb a large check.

title: Uber Picks N.S.A. Veteran to Fix Troubled Security Team
abstract: Matt Olsen, the former general counselof the National Security Agency, will replace Joe Sullivan, who was fired after the disclosure of a data breach.

title: Google-Facebook Dominance Hurts Ad Tech Firms, Speeding Consolidation
abstract: The investment of venture capital money into ad tech start-ups is falling sharply, helping push a wave of acquisitions.

title: How a Fake Group on Facebook Created Real Protests
abstract: The Black Elevation page held rallies, posted videos and encouraged the fight against racism. Whoever ran it even interviewed a job applicant.

title: Inside Twitter’s Struggle Over What Gets Banned
abstract: The social media company provided a rare look inside a policy meeting as it struggled with criticism that it left up posts from the conspiracy site Infowars and its creator, Alex Jones.

title: Apple’s Value Hit $1 Trillion. Add Disney to Bank of America and ... You’re Halfway There
abstract: A look at how Apple’s trillion-dollar value stacks up against other companies and entire industries.

title: A Generation Grows Up in China Without Google, Facebook or Twitter
abstract: Many foreign internet giants are blocked, leaving some young Chinese to wonder what those services even are — and reinforcing Beijing’s ideological control.

title: ‘The Beginning of a Wave’: A.I. Tiptoes Into the Workplace
abstract: Artificial intelligence software is making its presence felt in subtle ways, in an unglamorous place: the back office.

title: What Chrome Means by ‘Not Secure’
abstract: Google’s recent update to the browser warns users when websites aren’t automatically protecting their communication.

title: Alex Jones and Infowars Content Is Removed From Apple, Facebook and YouTube
abstract: Technology firms move to curb one of the loudest voices in conspiracy theories, fueling further debate over free speech online.

title: Facebook Banned Infowars. Now What?
abstract: Slippery-slope fears about mass censorship by social media platforms are probably overblown. But many valid questions remain.

title: Make Your Own Message Folders in Windows 10
abstract: If the standard set of folders that comes with the Windows 10 Mail program are not enough, you add and delete your own.

title: Wanted: ‘Lost Einsteins.’ Please Apply.
abstract: Pioneer, an experimental fund, is using the Silicon Valley model to find and nurture people who have talent but lack opportunity.

title: The Internet Trolls Have Won. Sorry, There’s Not Much You Can Do.
abstract: When it comes to online comments and discourse and what you can do to limit their toxicity, you only have a certain amount of power. The real leverage lies with the tech companies.

title: As Google Maps Renames Neighborhoods, Residents Fume
abstract: Google’s digital maps have become the world’s default atlas and the arbiter of what neighborhoods are called, even when many residents disagree.

title: Tech Companies Banned Infowars. Now, Its App Is Trending.
abstract: Days after Google, Facebook and Apple removed Infowars content, the app from the right-wing conspiracy site has surged in downloads.

title: F.B.I.’s Urgent Request: Reboot Your Router to Stop Russia-Linked Malware
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of home and office routers have been infected by the malware, which was created by the same group that hacked the Democratic National Committee.

title: How Uber Uses Psychological Tricks to Push Its Drivers’ Buttons
abstract: The start-up has undertaken an extraordinary experiment in behavioral science to subtly entice an independent work force to maximize company revenue.

title: The Security of Cellular Connections
abstract: That free Wi-Fi network may not be so free if it is unsecured and someone hijacks your data. Your phone’s cellular data connection offers more protection.
